choices.text: Risk of transitional cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder

questions.text: All of the following are features of bladder exstrophy except?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The risk of Adenocarcinoma is increased, not transitional cell carcinoma, in bladder exstrophy patients.

Features of Exstrophy of the Urinary Bladder Include:

  • Bladder Mucosa Exposed To The Outside: Associated with Total urinary incontinence and Risk of Adenocarcinoma of The Urinary Bladder
  • Downward displacement of the umbilicus
  • Widely separate pubic rami
  • Inguinal Hernias, Short Stature
  • Males: Epispadias, Shallow Scrotum, Short penile length
  • Females: Bifid Clitoris, Widely separated labia

questions.text: A healthy 6-month-old boy is found incidentally to have a duplicated collecting system with no dilation. He has been asymptomatic and has been growing well. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

In asymptomatic children with a duplicated collecting system and no dilation or infection, as in this healthy 6-month-old boy, no intervention is needed; observation is the appropriate management per standard guidelines.

  • A duplicated collecting system is the most common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract. It can be:
    • Partial duplication: Two pelvicalyceal systems drain into a single ureter that bifurcates proximally.
    • Complete duplication: Two separate ureters drain independently into the genitourinary tract.
  • Aetiology: Results from duplication of the ureteric bud during embryogenesis.
  • In complete duplication, the ureters insert into the bladder or ectopically, following the Weigert-Meyer rule:
    • The upper pole ureter inserts inferiorly and medially, often ectopically, and is prone to obstruction or ureterocele.
    • The lower pole ureter inserts superiorly and laterally, and is more commonly associated with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Clinical Relevance:
    • If asymptomatic, with no dilatation and no history of UTI, no intervention is required.
    • These cases can be safely managed with observation and periodic monitoring.

Reference:

  1. https://radiopaedia.org/articles/weigert-meyer-law

questions.text: A male infant was brought to the pediatric emergency department with abdominal distension and episodes of crying. He had not passed urine for 10 hours, and there was a history of urinary tract infection in the past. On examination, there is bladder fullness, suggesting urinary retention. The MCU image below was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Posterior urethral valve (PUV) is one of the most common causes of lower urinary tract obstruction in male children. These children present with dribbling, poor urinary stream, recurrent UTI and palpable bladder.

USG shows a keyhole appearance, but MCU is diagnostic in such patients.

questions.text: A child with recurrent UTI is most likely to show?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

VUR (Vesico-ureteric reflux) refers to the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the pelvis or ureters either during rest or during micturition.

  • Recurrent UTIs occur in 30-50% children, and major factors include female sex, age <6 months, Bladder bowel dysfunction, VUR, obstructive uropathy and repeated catheterisation.
  • VUR is the most common cause of recurrent UTI in children, overall as well as in females
  • PUV is a common cause of recurrent UTI only in males.

choices.text: The condition is more common in females and results from bladder outlet atresia.
Endoscopic valve ablation is the first-line treatment if renal function is preserved.
It rarely leads to chronic kidney disease or renal failure.
Vesicostomy is contraindicated in neonates with elevated creatinine.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male neonate presents with poor urinary stream, palpable bladder, and failure to thrive. He has had one episode of urinary tract infection. On examination, bladder distension is noted. A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) shows a dilated posterior urethra. His serum creatinine is mildly elevated. Which of the following statements is true regarding the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The clinical findings of a male neonate with poor urinary stream, palpable bladder, and history of UTI strongly point toward posterior urethral valves, the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in boys. In cases with preserved renal function, the definitive treatment is endoscopic valve ablation.

Posterior Urethral Valves (PUVs):

  • The most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children.
  • Affects 1 in 8,000 male births. (Option A)
  • Valves are leaflets in the prostatic urethra; the embryologic origin is unclear.
  • Cause variable degrees of urinary obstruction.
  • Neonatal & Childhood Presentation:
    • Neonatal signs: palpable bladder, weak urinary stream.
    • Later presentation: failure to thrive, UTIs, incontinence.
    • VCUG or perineal ultrasound is used for diagnosis.
  • Complications:
    • ~30% progress to ESRD or chronic renal insufficiency. (Option C)
    • Leads to dilated prostatic urethra, bladder muscle hypertrophy.
    • VUR in 50%; can lead to distal ureteral obstruction.
  • Definitive Treatment:
    • If renal function is normal, Endoscopic valve ablation. (Option B)
    • If the urethra is too small: Temporary vesicostomy followed by delayed ablation.
    • Persistent high creatinine suggests irreversible damage → consider vesicostomy. (Option D)

choices.text: Urological consultation for an immediate nephrectomy
Renal ultrasound at 3-6 months of age

questions.text: In a 1-month-old newborn, his parents note that a prenatal ultrasound showed a left multicystic dysplastic kidney. Since birth, he has been breastfeeding well and makes multiple wet diapers a day. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Asymptomatic infants with multicystic dysplastic kidney require serial ultrasounds starting at 3-6 months to monitor for cyst involution and compensatory growth of the contralateral kidney.

Multicystic Dysplastic Kidney (MCDK):

  • MCDK is a congenital renal anomaly where the kidney is replaced by multiple non-communicating cysts with no functioning renal tissue.
  • Usually unilateral and non-inherited.
  • Pathogenesis involves:
    • Abnormal ureteric bud origin/penetration → improper induction of metanephric blastema.
    • Can be caused by early obstructive uropathy, e.g., PUV or ureteral atresia.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Often detected prenatally via ultrasound.
    • May be non-palpable at birth.
    • Some cases show cyst regression in utero, leading to an absent kidney on postnatal imaging.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • Ultrasound shows:
      • Multiple non-communicating cysts of variable size.
      • No identifiable renal parenchyma.
    • VCUG not needed unless:
      • Contralateral hydronephrosis is present.
      • UTI
  • Management:
    • Controversial; most cases are managed conservatively.
    • Cysts regress in ~50% of cases by age 7 years.
    • Follow-up includes:
      • Every 3-6 months in the first year.
      • Then, ultrasound + BP monitoring every 6-12 months.
      • Ensure the solitary kidney is functioning normally.
  • Indications for Nephrectomy:
    • Enlarging cysts
    • Increasing stromal component
    • Abdominal mass
    • Development of hypertension

Explanation of other options:

WT1 gene mutation (Option A): WT1 mutation is associated with Wilms tumour and syndromic conditions (e.g., Denys-Drash), not isolated, unilateral MCDK.

Urological consultation for immediate nephrectomy (Option B): Nephrectomy is not routinely indicated in stable, asymptomatic infants, as most MCDKs involute spontaneously.

Sending of serum PTH (Option C): PTH is used to evaluate mineral-bone disorders, typically in chronic kidney disease, which is not suspected in this well-appearing infant.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of abdominal mass in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Multicystic dysplastic kidney - MCDK is the most common cause of an abdominal mass in the newborn, but the vast majority are nonpalpable at birth.

  • In most cases, it is discovered incidentally during prenatal sonography.
  • Contralateral hydronephrosis is present in 5-10% of patients. Sonography shows the characteristic appearance of a kidney replaced by multiple cysts of varying sizes that do not communicate, and no identifiable parenchyma is present.
  • Serial USGs done at 3 months initially and then every 6 months post-infancy show regression of the cysts.
  • Most cysts resolve by 7 years of age.

Common Pediatric Tumours:

References:

  1. https://pcrf-kids.org/most-common-childhood-cancers/

choices.text: Referral to a urologist or gynecologist for immediate surgery

questions.text: A healthy 9-month-old female infant is seen for a routine health supervision visit. On physical examination, a membrane connecting the labia minora that seems to cover most of the vaginal opening is seen. The parents do not report any symptoms and have been able to see a strong urine stream. Of the following, the BEST approach to the management of the examination finding is?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

As seen in the image, the child is having labial adhesions.

  • Asymptomatic children with labial adhesions do not require treatment.
  • Symptomatic children with labial adhesions should first undergo a trial of a topical estrogen cream.
  • Referral to a specialist for surgical lysis may be necessary for symptomatic labial adhesions that do not respond to conventional therapies.

questions.text: A newborn is evaluated shortly after birth. The image below was taken during the physical examination. Which of the following is not a likely associated anomaly?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Unilateral renal agenesis is often found to co-exist with:

  1. Single umbilical artery
  2. Absence of the Vas deferens on the same side
  3. Contralateral VUR
  4. Contralateral Renal hypertrophy
  5. Syndromes: MRKH Syndrome in females & Zinner Syndrome in males

Extra Edge Points:

  • MRKH Syndrome[Mullerian anomaly] [Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser]- Absence of uterus + Hypoplasia of upper part of vagina, but normally functioning ovaries
  • Zinner syndrome- Cyst in the seminal vesicle and epididymis, Usually Asymptomatic.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with this anomaly?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The image shows bladder exstrophy. Ventral chordee with hypospadias is not associated with bladder exstrophy; instead, affected males typically have dorsal chordee with epispadias.

Bladder Exstrophy:

  • Male: Female ratio is 2:1.
  • Severity ranges:
    • Simple epispadias (mild form)
    • Classic bladder exstrophy
    • Cloacal exstrophy (most severe, involves hindgut & bladder)
  • Embryology & Pathogenesis:
    • Due to the failure of mesodermal invasion of the cloacal membrane.
    • The timing and extent of failure determine the severity.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Bladder mucosa exposed through the abdominal wall.
    • Umbilicus displaced downward.
    • Widely separated pubic rami and rectus muscles. (Option A)
    • Anteriorly displaced anus, possible rectal prolapse. (Option B)
    • In Males:
      • Complete epispadias with dorsal chordee. (Option C)
      • Shortened penis (about half normal length).
      • Separated, shallow scrotum.
      • Common: Undescended testes & inguinal hernias. (Option D)
    • In Females:
      • Epispadias with split clitoris and wide-separated labia.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is associated with the congenital malformation shown?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The image shows Horseshoe kidneys, which are characterised by the fusion of the lower poles of the two kidneys in the midline.

  • About 7-30% cases are found to be associated with Turner Syndrome.
  • Most commonly, the left kidney crosses over and fuses with the lower pole of the right kidney.
  • The insertion of the ureter into the bladder does not change, and the adrenal glands remain in their normal positions.
  • The clinical significance of this anomaly is that if renal surgery is necessary, the blood supply is variable and can make partial nephrectomy more difficult.
  • Wilm's tumour tends to occur more commonly in horseshoe kidneys than in normal kidneys.

questions.text: The newborn infant of a 28 y primigravida has severe respiratory distress due to pulmonary hypoplasia and is noted to have pseudoepicanthus, flattened ears and nose, and bilateral club feet. There is no family history of renal failure. Abdominal ultrasonography reveals bilaterally enlarged echogenic kidneys with poor corticomedullary differentiation; there are no cysts or hydronephrosis. The liver, spleen, pancreas, and gallbladder are reported to be normal. Of the following, the MOST likely cause of this neonate's condition is?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The child has pulmonary hypoplasia producing severe respiratory distress, abnormal facies & bilateral clubfeet, with structural renal anomalies. All this suggests a diagnosis of Potter's Syndrome.

  • Potter syndrome/Potter sequence/oligohydramnios sequence is the characteristic phenotypic feature in the neonate caused by oligohydramnios.
  • The characteristic features include pulmonary hypoplasia(respiratory distress in the newborn), facial appearance (pseudoepicanthus, flattened ears and nose, recessed chin), and limb abnormalities (club feet and hip dislocation).
  • Types of Potter syndrome
    • Type I: Associated with ARPKD
    • Type II: Associated with renal agenesis or hereditary renal dysplasia
    • Type III: Associated with ADPKD
    • Type IV: Associated with obstructive uropathy and hydronephrosis
  • Potter syndrome type 1 occurs in association with ARPKD.
  • On ultrasonography, patients with ARPKD have enlarged echogenic kidneys without obvious renal cysts, whereas ADPKD is associated with macrocysts.

questions.text: An infant presented to a clinic with complaints of failure to thrive. On evaluation, the child had hypertension, hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Gordon Syndrome, also called familial hyperkalemic hypertension, is an inherited tubular disorder, comprising volume expansion with hypertension, hyperkalemia, hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, and hypercalciuria. The reason is excessive activation of the thiazide-sensitive sodium chloride co-transporter NCCT. The condition shows a good response to thiazide diuretics as therapeutic agents.

Also, note the clinical approach to inherited tubular disorders as follows:

questions.text: All of the following can be used to distinguish Bartter syndrome from Gitelman syndrome, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Both Bartter Syndrome & Gitelman Syndrome have hypokalemia, and thus serum potassium levels can't be used to distinguish between them.

Serum magnesium levels (Option C): Serum Mg is normal in Bartter and low in Gitelman.

Facial dysmorphism (Option D): Facial dysmorphism occurs in some forms of Bartter syndrome but not in Gitelman syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with poor growth, polyuria, polydipsia, and recurrent dehydration despite adequate intake. Examination reveals mild dehydration and normal blood pressure. Laboratory results reveal serum sodium 138 mEq/L, potassium 2.5 mEq/L, chloride 94 mEq/L, and bicarbonate 30 mEq/L. Arterial blood gas shows a pH of 7.48. Urinary calcium is elevated, and plasma renin activity is increased. His condition improves with indomethacin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The combination of hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, polyuria, and normal blood pressure suggests Bartter or Gitelman syndrome. Elevated urinary calcium favours Bartter syndrome, not Gitelman. Improvement with indomethacin further supports Bartter due to its link with increased renal prostaglandin E2. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Bartter syndrome.

choices.text: Most childhood UTI are caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae
All recurrent UTI need USG Abdomen on follow-up
MCU may be needed in recurrent UTI
Bladder and bowel dysfunction increases the risk of UTI in children

questions.text: Regarding childhood UTI, all of the following are true except?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • UTIs are caused primarily by colonic bacteria.
  • Escherichia coli causes 54-67% of all UTIs, followed by Klebsiella spp. and Proteus spp., Enterococcus, and Pseudomonas.
  • Other bacteria known to cause UTIs include Staphylococcus saprophyticus, group B streptococcus, and, less commonly, Staphylococcus aureus, Candida spp., and Salmonella spp.

Explanation of other options:

All recurrent UTIs need USG Abdomen on follow-up (Option B): All recurrent UTIs need USG Abdomen after therapy is over, to rule out any bladder-related anatomic abnormality as a cause of recurrent UTIs.

MCU may be needed in recurrent UTI (Option C): MCU, also called VCUG, is recommended in recurrent UTI as a part of work-up for likely aetiology & rule out Vesico-Ureteric Reflux (VUR).

Bladder and bowel dysfunction increases the risk of UTI in children (Option D): In a child with recurrent UTIs, identification of predisposing factors is beneficial. Bowel and bladder dysfunction is a very important contributor to recurrent UTIs and is one of the main reasons for an increase in UTIs around the time of toilet training.

choices.text: Ultrasound scan within 6 weeks of infection

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with fever and a poor urine stream. Urinalysis confirms a urinary tract infection. He improves within 48 hours of antibiotics. What is the next appropriate imaging according to NICE guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The child is <6 months and has an atypical UTI (poor urine stream). NICE recommends ultrasound during the acute infection in such cases.

NICE Recommended Imaging Schedule for UTI in Children:

Explanation of other options:

DMSA scan at 6 weeks (Option B): DMSA is not done at 6 weeks; it is done at 4-6 months after infection in atypical or recurrent cases.

VCUG immediately (Option C): VCUG is not routinely done unless the ultrasound shows abnormalities or specific risk factors are present.

Ultrasound scan within 6 weeks of infection (Option D): This is done in uncomplicated UTI in children <6 months, not when atypical features are present.

choices.text: Most commonly caused by Proteus mirabilis
Can be associated with constipation and bowel dysfunction
Prevention is best achieved by long-term amoxicillin

questions.text: Regarding Urinary tract infections in children, the true statement is?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Risk factors for UTI include:

  • Female gender
  • Underlying VUR
  • Constipation
  • Neurological problems involving the bladder and bowel(spina bifida, operated sacro-coocygeal teratoma, etc.
  • Bladder-bowel dysfunction (BBD) can cause recurrent UTI in Children.

Explanation of other options:

Usually leads to vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) (Option A): VUR is usually a cause of UTI rather than a result.

Most commonly caused by Proteus mirabilis (Option B): E coli is the commonest organism isolated from UTIs.

Prevention is best achieved by long-term amoxicillin (Option D): Long-term agents like Cotrimoxazole, Cephalexin, Cefadroxil and Nitrofurantoin are usually used as prophylactic agents. Amoxicillin is useful in treating UTI, but not recommended for the prevention of UTI.

questions.text: A girl child presents with complaints of constant dribbling of urine since birth. She is, however, also able to void voluntarily. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Clues include constant urinary dribbling, with preserved ability to voluntarily pass urine, also in a girl child. This indicates a likely diagnosis of Ectopic Ureter.

  • The female-to-male ratio is 2-6:1
  • Ureteral ectopia, or Ectopic Ureters, is usually associated with a duplicated collecting system in females.
  • The condition refers to a ureter that drains outside the bladder, often into the vagina or distal urethra.
  • It can produce urinary incontinence characterised by constant urinary dribbling all day, even though the child voids regularly.
  • Treatment in these cases is either partial nephrectomy, with removal of the upper pole segment of the duplicated kidney and its ureter down to the pelvic brim, or ipsilateral ureteroureterostomy, in which the upper pole ectopic ureter is anastomosed to the normally positioned lower pole ureter.
  • These procedures are often performed by minimally invasive laparoscopy with or without robotic assistance.

questions.text: STING Procedure is employed in the management of which among the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Sub-ureteric Transurethral Injection of a Bulking Agent in VUR is also called the STING Procedure.

  • Using a Cystoscope, a bulking agent is injected into the submucosal plane of the intramural part of the ureter
  • This narrows the ureteric orifice and reinforces the flap-valve mechanism, reducing reflux.
  • Increasingly being used as an alternative to surgery in VUR patients.
